title: Dudleya saxosa subsp. saxosa
text:
Dudleya saxosa subsp. "saxosa" is a species of <a href="Succulent%20plant">succulent</a> <a href="Perennial%20plant">perennial</a> plant <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> only to the western <a href="Panamint%20Range">Panamint Range</a> of <a href="California">California</a>. It is known commonly as the Panamint liveforever or Panamint dudleya. It is found on north-facing, <a href="Granitoid">granitic</a> or <a href="limestone">limestone</a> slopes and grows up to 20 cm wide. It is characterized by bright yellow, red tinged flowers, which bloom from May to June.
Description.
This species grows from basal <a href="Rosette%20%28botany%29">rosettes</a> which emerge from a <a href="caudex">caudex</a>. The caudex is 1 to 1.5 cm in diameter. There are 1 to 4 rosettes per plant, which can be 6 to 20 cm wide. The <a href="Leaf">leaves</a> are 3 to 9 cm long, 3 to 15 mm wide, and 1.5 to 3 mm thick, with the base 5 to 15 mm wide.
The <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a> emerges from a peduncle 5 to 20 cm tall, and 2 to 4 mm wide. The lower <a href="Plant%20stem">internodes</a> are generally greater than 5 mm apart. There are 3 first degree branches, with the terminal branches (cincinni) not wavy, the terminal branches 1 to 4 cm long, 2 to 9 flowered. The pedicels are 5 to 10 mm long. The <a href="flower">flower</a> has <a href="Petal">petals</a> that are 9 to 12 mm long, colored bright yellow, and generally tinged with red.
Taxonomy.
This species was described as "Cotyledon saxosum" by <a href="Marcus%20E.%20Jones">Marcus E. Jones</a>, based on a plant he found growing in Panamint Canyon in 1897. In their revision of North American <a href="Crassulaceae">Crassulaceae</a>, <a href="Nathaniel%20Lord%20Britton">Nathaniel Lord Britton</a> and <a href="Joseph%20Nelson%20Rose">Joseph Nelson Rose</a> placed this species as "Dudleya saxosa". It was reduced to an <a href="Autonym%20%28botany%29">autonym</a>, "Dudleya saxosa" subsp. "saxosa" with <a href="Reid%20Venable%20Moran">Reid Moran</a>'s subsequent changes to the taxonomy of "Dudleya".
The plant is a well-isolated <a href="Polyploidy">polyploid</a> compared to the other subspecies of "Dudleya saxosa", differing in its smaller size. It has a <a href="Ploidy">chromosome number</a> of 2"n" = 136 and 2"n" = 170.
Distribution and habitat.
This species is found growing on north-facing, granitic or limestone cliffs and rocky slopes. It is found only in the western <a href="Panamint%20Range">Panamint Mountains</a> of <a href="California">California</a>.
